awd_titl_txt: Turbulent structures in the magnetic interstellar medium
awd_abstract_narration:
The Interstellar Medium (ISM) is the stuff that fills the space between the stars in our Galaxy.  The ISM includes ionized gas and a variety of molecules, as well as dust threaded with magnetic fields. The investigators will learn how magnetic fields interact to form new structures in interstellar gas and dust. They will better understand turbulence and magnetism in galaxies. This project is important because the magnetic structures in our galaxy obscures objects much farther away. By better understanding our galaxy, they hope to detect faint signals that provide clues on how our universe began. The investigators will pilot a new summer research experience for formerly incarcerated undergraduate students. They hope to enable these students to begin careers in science and technology. Graduate students will develop data visualization tools used in scientific and public outreach talks.	

This project will combine archival Arecibo Observatory neutral hydrogen data with new dust polarization maps from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope to quantify the coherence of the magnetic field between the warm and cold neutral media, and to characterize the spatial structure of dust polarization on small angular scales. Their work will also use archival Zeeman splitting measurements to make a new determination of properties of the magnetic field and of magnetohydrodynamic turbulence in the diffuse interstellar medium. The code and data products produced in this work will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The interstellar medium is the material between the stars in our Milky Way Galaxy. Far from being empty, the space between the stars contains dust and gas in a wide range of physical states. At the extreme ends of this range of states, some regions of the interstellar medium are dominated by diffuse plasma, and other regions by the cold, dense, molecular clouds from which new stars are born. The structure and evolution of the interstellar environment are poorly understood, but are critical to our understanding of the physics of star formation and the evolution of gas in galaxies. The interstellar medium is turbulent, and pervaded by weak interstellar magnetic fields. It is thus an ideal laboratory for the study of magnetic fields and magnetic turbulence, on physical scales and in physical environments that are unrealizable in a terrestrial setting. Additionally, polarized emission from dust in the interstellar medium is a major impediment to our understanding of early-universe cosmology. The interstellar emission obscures faint signals in the polarized cosmic microwave background, the relic radiation from when the universe was very young. 

 This project supported investigations of the structure and properties of the magnetic interstellar medium, using a variety of data: measurements of interstellar emission and absorption at different wavelengths, including in polarization. Our team found new, quantitative descriptions of the link between the filamentary structure of gas in the interstellar medium and the statistical properties of polarized interstellar dust emission. We discovered an imprint of the structure of the three-dimensional distribution of dust in the nearby Galaxy on this polarized dust emission. These results have implications not just for our understanding of the magnetic interstellar medium, but also for the treatment of cosmological foregrounds. We additionally investigated the link between the thermodynamic state of interstellar gas and the properties of the interstellar magnetic field. We were able to place new, quantitative constraints on the degree of magnetic disorder across different phases of the interstellar gas. These novel observational constraints will be used to test theories of magnetic turbulence in the interstellar medium.

Multiple graduate students and undergraduate students were trained in the course of this research. This project also supported summer research internships for formerly incarcerated undergraduate students. These students participated in summer research with the PI and her research group. Students reported learning new skills, strong professional development, and increased motivation to pursue meaningful work in their future careers that would have strong, positive societal impacts.
